). In patients without perforation, a cholesteatoma may appear as a subtle whitish discoloration behind an otherwise normal tympanic membrane. A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinized, desquamated epithelial cells in the middle ear or mastoid, although it does not contain cholesterol or lipids; it is not a neoplasm. Cholesteatomas are usually caused by eustachian tube dysfunction that results in tympanic membrane retraction and inflammatory changes in a pocket behind the retracted membrane. Epithelial debris accumulates in this pocket, grows with continued inflammation and infection, and may eventually erode into middle ear or mastoid structures.
